31407.description: Course examines the basic concepts, key terms and roles of all essential players for both the venue management and touring and concert promotion industry and the relationships between venues, booking agents, tour managers and media.

31408.description: Course examines the basic concepts, key terms and roles of all essential players for both the venue management and touring and concert promotion industry and the relationships between venues, booking agents, tour managers and media.

31326.description: Sound recording techniques are presented to provide Music Industry Business Concentration students with basic recording competency through practical application. Students are required to create several recordings through projects that require teamwork and self-analysis.

33457.description: Sound recording techniques are presented to provide Music Industry Business Concentration students with basic recording competency through practical application. Students are required to create several recordings through projects that require teamwork and self-analysis.

30584.description: Basic sound recording procedures are presented with an emphasis on microphone techniques, signal-flow, and session workflow. Requires students to create several multitrack recordings, including editing and mixing.

31327.course_title: Contracts and Legal Issues in the Music Industry
31327.prereqs: MIP 161  Minimum Grade: D and BLAW 201  Minimum Grade: D
31327.description: This course explores contractual agreements and the legal issues affecting the music industry today, such as free speech in radio and music lyrics, rights of publicity for recording artists, fair use and piracy, as well as the various standard agreements in common use in the music and recording industries.

32024.description: Students present Extra Curricular recording projects to the instructor and fellow students for an in-class critique. The in-class critique will give the student direct feedback on their creative work and allow them to compare their work against the work of their peers. The production critiques will be moderated by the instructor and grades will be assessed based on in-class participation and presentations

32025.description: Students present Extra Curricular recording projects to the instructor and fellow students for an in-class critique. The in-class critique will give the student direct feedback on their creative work and allow them to compare their work against the work of their peers. The production critiques will be moderated by the instructor and grades will be assessed based on in-class participation and presentations

31479.description: MAD Dragon Music Group is designed to immerse students in the world of the independent music business and includes all of the professor led, student operated enterprises that create, organize and administer MAD Dragon Music Group projects.

33941.description: This course explores and celebrates women¿s contributions to the music industry in a variety of roles and capacities. Students will be empowered and encouraged to reflect on the significance of equity and representation in today¿s industry landscape through examining women¿s experiences, challenges, and accomplishments as business people and creatives. This course involves extensive student discussions, critique, and group project work. Through the analysis of recent studies, students will gain a deeper understanding of the current landscape and trends as it relates to gender representation in the music industry, including the intersectionality of gender with other identities, as well as active and proposed efforts that aim to support and advocate for equality. Additionally, this course examines the impacts and obstacles of women in the music industry throughout history and in specific sectors of the music industry, and how social constructs have contributed to gender perception in the workplace, in the media, and beyond. To deepen students¿ personal perspectives on representation in the music industry and prepare them for their careers in today¿s increasingly diverse workforce, students have the opportunity to engage with music industry professionals about their experiences and how gender has played a role in their trajectories.

34717.description: A reading, writing, discussion and listening -based course taught through case studies of iconic albums. Students will be challenged to answer the questions: How do some records become wildly successful, in spite of being universally panned by critics? And why do some highly anticipated releases fail, while certain artists rise to the top of the charts in defiance of commerciality?

34256.description: A reading, writing, discussion and listening -based course taught through case studies of iconic albums. Students will be challenged to answer the questions: How do some records become wildly successful, in spite of being universally panned by critics? And why do some highly anticipated releases fail, while certain artists rise to the top of the charts in defiance of commerciality?

34257.description: This course provides an overview of how radio and music streaming is used in record promotion and artist development and includes both theory and practical applications.

31480.description: Introduces the student to basic maintenance and troubleshooting techniques used in the modern recording studio. Basic electronic components, cabling, soldering skills, audio measurements, and equipment calibration are emphasized.

33939.description: This course focuses on advanced Digital Audio Workstation techniques used in modern audio production. This course will explore trends in DAW technology and showcase emerging production techniques used in the creation of modern music.

31328.description: Students will gain an historical perspective on the evolving role of the Manager from an entrepreneurial perspective. The class examines the core components that comprise an artist's professional team. The course will explore and analyze the central role that managers in particular, but also, attorneys, agents, business managers, services firms, record labels and other entities each play in representing, developing, and supervising the artist¿s overall business and brand.

32026.description: The students in this class learn contemporary music production techniques through a combination of lecture, demonstration and independent work.

32027.description: The students in this class learn contemporary music production techniques through a combination of lecture, demonstration and independent work.

31647.description: Senior Project is a thesis course in which student groups engage over the three quarters of senior year in intensive research on a topic selected by a jury among individual proposals.   The thesis will result in some form of publishable material.  The student will present their thesis to a jury in their final quarter of senior year.

31451.description: Provides practical experience as a participant in a Department of Performing Arts community arts initiative. Includes involvement with off campus activities with community members under faculty supervision and direction.

30946.description: Lecture-laboratory course in black and white photography. With a combination of lectures, assignments and group critiques, students learn to see photographically through an exploration of the basic tools, techniques and aesthetics of photography. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

32355.description: This course is an introduction to the manipulation and output of files using Photoshop and Lightroom. Skills acquired include working with RAW files, density, contrast and color correction, basic retouching, compositing of image, type and color elements along with special effects and output via inkjet printer. A digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or greater is required that is capable of shooting in RAW file format.

30952.description: Continues the aesthetic and technical investigations of black and white photography begun in PHTO 110 through a mix of lectures, slide discussions, analytical and creative projects, and group critiques. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or higher is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

31711.description: Continues the aesthetic and technical investigations of black and white photography begun in PHTO 110 through a mix of lectures, slide discussions, analytical and creative projects, and group critiques. For PHTO Majors, a manual 35mm film camera is required. For PHTO Minors & non-majors a digital point and shoot camera or DSLR, 16 megapixels or higher is required. Cameras that are capable of shooting in RAW format are strongly recommended.

32356.description: This course will introduce students to the foundations of color photography. It is a lecture-laboratory course that combines the visual, technical, and communicative properties of color photography with comprehensive color digital workflow experience. Students will begin to master the techniques of properly color balancing their prints and develop a sense of how to use color. It is important to grasp the foundations of color photography, but it is equally important to understand the aesthetic implications that using color entails.

31712.description: Provides an overview of the history of photography from approximately 1930 to the present, including technological developments, aesthetic trends, theoretical and philosophical understandings, and effects on society and culture at large.

33114.description: An advanced studio photography class that will teach the student the workflow associated with high-end digital studio capture.  The class will also cover various advanced studio lighting techniques.  The development of a personal portfolio of work produced in the studio will be required by all students.

33856.description: An advanced studio photography class that will teach the student the workflow associated with high-end digital studio capture.  The class will also cover various advanced studio lighting techniques.  The development of a personal portfolio of work produced in the studio will be required by all students.

34816.prereqs: PHTO 140  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 240  Minimum Grade: D
34816.description: This class will build on intermediate Photoshop skills while exploring the new field of building a photographic image by using more than one frame or multiple elements.  Students will be expected to produce a body of work using the skills learned.  Large format printing will be stressed.

33115.prereqs: PHTO 234  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 233  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 236  Minimum Grade: D
33115.description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

33857.prereqs: PHTO 234  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 233  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 236  Minimum Grade: D
33857.description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

33116.prereqs: PHTO 233  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 361  Minimum Grade: D
33116.description: This class explores the technical and aesthetic aspects of the 19th century, hand-coated palladium and platinum printing processes. Students will use large format negatives to produce a body of work.  This course will include hand-coating techniques, paper and chemistry options.

30256.prereqs: PHTO 492  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 493  Minimum Grade: D
30256.description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project. Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

34606.prereqs: PHTO 492  Minimum Grade: D and PHTO 493  Minimum Grade: D
34606.description: Integrates the technical and conceptual understandings that the student has acquired in photography through development of a personally defined photographic project.  Students will meet in weekly seminars to plan, discuss, and critique in-progress work.

33476.description: This course is devoted to the final development of your senior thesis project. We will be preparing your work for the final senior thesis exhibition. This will include the final selection of work, sequencing, printing and framing of the work.

32357.course_title: History and Analysis of Product Design
32357.description: This class studies the chronological context of the development of the product design profession, relating it to the social, cultural and economic events that helped shape our modern day society.  Studies are focuses on major industrial designers and innovations.  This course has both a project and written analysis paper component.

31468.description: This course is a studio-seminar introducing principles and theories of product design, systematic design process, problem-solving, decision making and design as authorship.  The course uses design research methods, and topical design issues to explore and expierience design thinking.

30789.prereqs: PROD 210  Minimum Grade: C and PROD 220  Minimum Grade: C
30789.description: In this course students are presented complex design issues in mass-produced objects. Students develop an understanding of the product development process focusing on the designers skills and technical knowledge to formulate appropriate design solutions. Students practice collaboration of ideas with engineers, marketing, users and shareholders.

31025.prereqs: PROD 210  Minimum Grade: C and PROD 220  Minimum Grade: C
31025.description: In this course students are presented complex design issues in mass-produced objects. Students develop an understanding of the product development process focusing on the designers skills and technical knowledge to formulate appropriate design solutions. Students practice collaboration of ideas with engineers, marketing, users and shareholders.

34210.description: This course explores the various types of visual communication and presentation fundamentals applying the layout and composition type, color, images, and graphic assets used in product and visual presentation applications.

34211.description: This course explores the various types of visual communication and presentation fundamentals applying the layout and composition type, color, images, and graphic assets used in product and visual presentation applications.

34212.description: This course will focus on the art and design of building quality speakers. Students will be expected to design and build either a bluetooth speaker or a set of bookshelf speakers. Students will learn how to select drivers, crossovers as well as learn how to calculate the right size enclosure to get the optimum sound out of your speakers. Students will be expected to make a well-crafted and good sounding set of speakers as a final assignment.

30945.description: This final studio is a culmination of the educational experience in the production of a senior exhibition highlighting the students' accomplishments.  Under supervision, students work together to demonstrate control of all aspects of the design process and visual communication in the production of a graduation exhibition.

32358.description: This final studio is a culmination of the educational experience in the production of a senior exhibition highlighting the students' accomplishments.  Under supervision, students work together to demonstrate control of all aspects of the design process and visual communication in the production of a graduation exhibition.

31713.description: Students will read branding case studies to comprehend why the phenomena of branding continues to drive our consumer society. Intellectual property rights, ethics and the legality surrounding various types of products and their branding will be investigated as students understand how to engage consumers in the global branding process.

31714.description: This course focuses on integrated retail buying and merchandise management and strategy development using technology. Students explore and analyze past, current and future trends in ecommerce technologies that primarily support the back end inventory, logistics and front end operations of the fashion apparel, accessory and home products industries.

34652.description: This course will be taught in a seminar format and feature talks from various leadership areas in the retail, merchandising, and lifestyle product areas. Topics will consider how managers and leaders must develop teams to understand corporate culture, retail management & analysis, product quality, customer service, human resources, merchandising strategies, and future goals.

31715.prereqs: RMER 500  Minimum Grade: B and RMER 510  Minimum Grade: B
31715.description: This rigorous course is designed to develop understanding and experience in empirical research in order to build and design a final project or thesis. Emphasis will be placed on data collection, organization, interpretation and presentation. Students will follow-up with their instructor through web-based platforms and will be required to turn-in reports and output for their project or thesis.

31716.prereqs: RMER 500  Minimum Grade: B and RMER 510  Minimum Grade: B
31716.description: This final course will build the student¿s concentrated coursework producing a finalized project or thesis (such as a publishable academic journal article) synthesizing an area of Retail & Merchandising based upon their specific research and data collection. Students will be responsible for working with their course professor on the final outcome that documents the proposal, base research and conclusions.

31672.description: This course introduces students to the core building blocks of ¿story¿ from the perspective of the entertainment industry, where stories are produced for mediums other than literary: film, television, the stage, graphic novels, or video games. Through readings, lectures, discussions and screenings, the class delves into the unique considerations of stories created or adapted for production as visual entertainment artifacts. Analytic examinations of core story-telling differences between various mediums will also be highlighted, to give students insight in later production and studies courses in their chosen medium of expression.

33043.description: This course introduces students to the core building blocks of ¿story¿ from the perspective of the entertainment industry, where stories are produced for mediums other than literary: film, television, the stage, graphic novels, or video games. Through readings, lectures, discussions and screenings, the class delves into the unique considerations of stories created or adapted for production as visual entertainment artifacts. Analytic examinations of core story-telling differences between various mediums will also be highlighted, to give students insight in later production and studies courses in their chosen medium of expression.

35262.description: This course introduces students to the core building blocks of ¿story¿ from the perspective of the entertainment industry, where stories are produced for mediums other than literary: film, television, the stage, graphic novels, or video games. Through readings, lectures, discussions and screenings, the class delves into the unique considerations of stories created or adapted for production as visual entertainment artifacts. Analytic examinations of core story-telling differences between various mediums will also be highlighted, to give students insight in later production and studies courses in their chosen medium of expression.

31151.description: Introduces the basic tenets of playwriting and applies their use towards the writing of a 10-minute play.

34565.description: Deals with the conception, writing and performance of a stand-up comedy routine.  Includes exploration of creating a comic persona, structuring an act, construction of jokes, and aspects relating to perfromance.  "Final exam" will be given before a live audience at a public venue.

30254.prereqs: ENGL 101  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 105  Minimum Grade: D
30254.description: Workshop course that covers the fundamentals of writing scripts for film and television. This is a writing intensive course.

30563.prereqs: ENGL 101  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 105  Minimum Grade: D
30563.description: Workshop course that covers the fundamentals of writing scripts for film and television. This is a writing intensive course.

30437.prereqs: ENGL 101  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 105  Minimum Grade: D
30437.description: Workshop course that covers the fundamentals of writing scripts for film and television. This is a writing intensive course.

30858.prereqs: ENGL 101  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 105  Minimum Grade: D
30858.description: Workshop course that covers the fundamentals of writing scripts for film and television. This is a writing intensive course.

31527.description: This course will focus on creating scripts for films under thirty minutes in length. This is a writing intensive course.

31415.description: Encourages students to use their knowledge of the current state of the art in gaming, and their technical and writing interests and expertise, to imagine games that go beyond those currently available.  Of particular interest are ways to create branching narratives that deliver the story satisfaction and character development expected from traditional media.

30290.description: This course provides a thorough understanding of methods used to develop story ideas from initial concept to complete screen story, including pitching, structuring, and creating treatments.  Students pitch and develop several stories which can then be used to create full-length scripts in advanced workshops.

30969.description: This course provides a thorough understanding of methods used to develop story ideas from initial concept to complete screen story, including pitching, structuring, and creating treatments.  Students pitch and develop several stories which can then be used to create full-length scripts in advanced workshops.

30255.prereqs: SCRP 275  Minimum Grade: D or SCRP 370  Minimum Grade: D
30255.description: The first of a two-course sequence in which students write a feature film script, telefilm, or television pilot.

34692.description: The second of a two-course sequence in which students write a feature film script, telefilm, or television pilot.

32013.description: The first of a two-course sequence in which students write a 90-minute, two-act play.

32688.course_title: Senior Project in Dramatic Writing III
32688.description: The third of a three-course sequence in which students write a feature film script, telelfilm, full-length stage play, television pilot, at least two spec episodes of an existing one-hour TV drama or four of an existing TV comedy.

32689.course_title: Senior Project in Dramatic Writing III
32689.description: The third of a three-course sequence in which students write a feature film script, telelfilm, full-length stage play, television pilot, at least two spec episodes of an existing one-hour TV drama or four of an existing TV comedy.

32423.description: This course covers recent trends in television, whether on streaming services, premium channels, cable, or on network channels.  The focus will be on television shows that have notable narrative and artistic characteristics early on, possibly foretelling their emergence as culturally significant later on.

32424.description: This course covers recent trends in television, whether on streaming services, premium channels, cable, or on network channels.  The focus will be on television shows that have notable narrative and artistic characteristics early on, possibly foretelling their emergence as culturally significant later on.

31673.description: We will examine television shows from the 1950's to the present that include vampires, werewolves, witches, ghosts, demons, monsters, and other beings with unusual abilities that arise from myths, legends, fairytales, and folktales (and not from scientific fact.) We will explore a variety of supernatural themes in television drama, including those that reflect our fears of the unknown and our desires to be more than we are. We will also discuss what goes into creating a high-caliber supernatural drama television show, looking at both the content and the form.  We will discuss the writing, the directing, the production design, the camerawork, the sound, the editing, and the special effects.

32864.description: Commercial media today are almost solely dependent on advertising revenue for their profitability and ultimate survival in a multichannel marketplace. This course will examine the process of revenue generation by local stations, cable operators, broadcast and cable networks; the structure of sales departments, interaction with other departments (news, programming, engineering, finance, promotion, public affairs) and will look at the customer base from the viewpoint of the media seller and media buyer.  We will also look at the human side of the equation; how sales teams are hired, motivated, coached, compensated, and evaluated.  Additionally, we will examine the role of sports, websites, programming decisions and Nielsen ratings and their effects on sales.

32865.description: Media Ethics for TVMN explores issues central to the decision-making process in which media mangers engage.  Case studies in television and evolving media, investigation of contemporary events that reflect ethical dilemmas, and research into the intersection of financial, regulatory, and career considerations with ethical choice are closely examined.

30637.description: This course offers hands-on management experience at Drexel's television station or (with Program Director's approval) at other television stations, cable companies, or related media.  The assumption is that the student will work a minimum of ten hours per week for ten weeks to receive three credits for the term.

32866.description: Content of the course will include: development of research proposals, hypothesis formulation and testing, research question structuring, methods for analyzing institutional dynamics, content analysis, regulatory and legal research, case study, and data mining linked with big data analytics tools.  It will also include an introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics. Laboratories will provide hands-on experience in the research process.

32693.description: This course is designed to provide faculty advising and library resources as students complete their capstone projects.

32694.description: This course is designed to provide faculty advising and library resources as students complete their capstone projects.

32381.description: A beginning course in speech for the stage.  The study of standard American speech, techniques for vocal projection, oral interpretation and the effective use of the voice on stage.

30877.description: Philadelphia Theatre Let's Go! exposes students to the variety of theatrical opportunities available in the Philadelphia region.  Through research, discussion and attendance at theatrical productions, students will enhance their abilities to discuss, evaluate and enjoy theatre.

31031.description: Philadelphia Theatre Let's Go! exposes students to the variety of theatrical opportunities available in the Philadelphia region.  Through research, discussion and attendance at theatrical productions, students will enhance their abilities to discuss, evaluate and enjoy theatre.

31351.description: Provides an introduction to the tools, equipment and basic procedures required to enable students to participate in the technical aspects of a theatrical production.

30817.description: Provides practical experience in acting for the stage. Requires student to play a role in a Department of Performing Arts theatre production. May be repeated for credit.

30077.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

30820.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

30821.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

30822.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

30823.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

31352.description: Provides practical experience in theatre production. Requires students to participate in planning, preparation, and completion of a realized production as a crew head or crew member. May be repeated for credit.

31428.description: This class provides practical experience in Theatre Management including Production Management, Stage Management, Box Office Management, and other Administrative Management areas for live theatrical events. Students are required to participate in a production for the Theatre Program.

31371.description: Students will gain hands on experience running a performance venue on campus.  Students are responsible for daily operations of Late Night Series Productions including: financial operations, strategic planning, artistic management, volunteer coordination, strategic partnerships, artist recruitment and management, marketing, and internet presence.  Also all production elements including: sound design and operation, light design and operation, and stage management and run crew.

31372.description: The Theater Performance Ensemble focuses on a specific area of performance training, creation, and research to supplement the standard theater curriculum in performance.  Each quarter focuses on a specific area with emphasis on learning as an ensemble and a priority on developing new skills.

31373.description: The Theater Performance Ensemble focuses on a specific area of performance training, creation, and research to supplement the standard theater curriculum in performance.  Each quarter focuses on a specific area with emphasis on learning as an ensemble and a priority on developing new skills.

31374.description: This course provides practical experience in acting for the stage through participation in a student directed one-act play in conjunction with the Play Directing Class.

31723.description: An introductory course for singers and non-singers emphasizing applying acting techniques to the performance of a song.  Focus will be placed on lyrics, and advancing dramatic action through the song.  The class will conclude with a public performance of the material students have worked on in class.

32391.prereqs: THTR 209  Minimum Grade: C  (THTR 209  may be taken concurrently with THTR 145)
32391.description: This course provides practical experience in various forms of Theater Improvisation. Students will put basic skills into practice including listening, building relationships in a trusting ensemble, risk-taking, letting go of fear, spontaneity, and being present.  This course will lead to a public presentation of the skills learned.

30154.description: Introductory acting course. Covers basic exercises, improvisations, fundamentals of voice production, and stage movement.

30436.description: Introductory acting course. Covers basic exercises, improvisations, fundamentals of voice production, and stage movement.

30552.description: Continues THTR 210. Intermediate course in acting, focusing on application of the techniques of acting through scene study.

30553.description: This course explores the various techniques employed by sketch comedians to imagine and create scripts which spring from a specific point of view.  Through exercises and assignments, sketch comedy will be explored as it relates to collaborates writing, improvisation, character development and the rehearsal process.

33487.description: The Musical is one of America¿s greatest contributions to the world of theatre.  Through class discussions, viewing live performance, audio/video examples, and readings students will analyze the changes in the American Musical form beginning in the 1960s to the present and predict its future direction.

30200.description: Uses lectures, discussions, and practical experience to introduce the processes and equipment used in the production of plays, including scenery construction, lighting, sound, and costuming.

34661.description: Sound design for theater has changed dramatically in the last few years.  Plays as well as musicals are incorporating sound scores that rival movies.  Sound designers for theater are in high demand, but in Philadelphia there is a shortage of people to fill these positions.  A sound designer needs to be a combination of an audio engineer and an artist that can create musical content that advances storytelling.  This class will introduce students to the fundamentals of sound design for theater.

30157.prereqs: THTR 211  Minimum Grade: D and THTR 121  Minimum Grade: D
30157.description: Introduces the art of directing, including play analysis, interpretation, rehearsal procedures, techniques of blocking, composition, picturization, and director-actor communications.

34645.description: This course explores the spaces between buildings in an urban environment, their ¿publicness¿, and the programming that takes place within them. Critical assessment of public spaces will be key to the class, including how they are used, who is and is not included in the everyday use and creation of these spaces, and how best to design and maintain public space through placemaking principles. .

33085.description: Second of two Thesis recitation seminars. Engagement in discourse and evaluation of self and peer investigations. Intended to foster healthy competition, accountability and peer evaluation.

33086.description: Third quarter of a three quarter thesis investigation. Application, documentation and presentation of research, analysis and proposed resolution of an attributable urban issue facing cities of today and in the future.  Professionally juried.

33927.description: Third quarter of a three quarter thesis investigation. Application, documentation and presentation of research, analysis and proposed resolution of an attributable urban issue facing cities of today and in the future.  Professionally juried.

35259.description: This course allows the student to work with a thesis advisor to complete the thesis. This optional course will be taken only by students needing more than two terms to complete the thesis.

34215.description: This multi-discipline course is bringing together brand strategy & merchandising (D&M) with the immersive media experience of the Digital Media program. Students will explore digital solutions for the business of fashion and develop solutions using immersive media in virtual & real space. Groups will combine students from Design and Merchandising & Digital Media to explore opportunities to plan and implement immersive solutions specific to the textile, fashion, and lifestyle industries.

34809.description: In this class, students use Unreal Engine to learn real-time graphics engine virtual filmmaking techniques for creating narrative virtual productions. Topics include set/location/world building, lighting, camera setup and movement, digital human character creation, animation and final rendering. Students will use these techniques to complete a narrative capstone project in the form of an animated short or previsualization of a planned, traditional film scene which could serve as tool for production planning or fund raising for a traditional short film production.

34261.description: Students learn to use motion capture systems for full-body, human performance capture as well as the processing and use of the resulting data in character animation and real-time/game engine applications.

34929.description: Students learn to use motion capture systems for full-body, human performance capture, as well as the processing and use of the resulting data in character animation and real-time/game engine applications. This class further incorporates the use of these principles and tools in live, real-time interaction and performance settings.

30712.description: Focuses on two-dimensional space, black and white, and appropriate tools and materials.

30309.prereqs: VSST 101  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 104  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 108  Minimum Grade: D
30309.description: Expands the visual vocabulary to include color theory. Continues the process of discovery and visual decision-making.

30019.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
30019.description: Covers the perception and ordering of three-dimensional space. Includes new methods and materials in the continuing process.

30020.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
30020.description: Covers the perception and ordering of three-dimensional space. Includes new methods and materials in the continuing process.

31024.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
31024.description: This Design III course is open to all students with the required prerequisites from design foundation courses. This course will begin with a recycled garment project that will culminate in a runway show event. The remainder of the course will follow the standard Design III curriculum. Students will work in and outside of the studio to develop their recycled garments as a design agenda.

31153.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
31153.description: Covers the perception and ordering of three-dimensional space. Includes new methods and materials in the continuing process.

31529.description: Covers the perception and ordering of three-dimensional space. Includes new methods and materials in the continuing process.

32021.description: This is an introductory course in which students will learn and use the essential concepts and language associated with design employing a variety of both black and white and color media combining hand and computer approaches.

30661.description: Introductory color design course for media majors combining hand and computer approaches. Builds on the design lesions of VSST 108 Design I for Media.

30663.description: Introductory color design course for media majors combining hand and computer approaches. Builds on the design lesions of VSST 108 Design I for Media.

33090.description: Introductory color design course for media majors combining hand and computer approaches.  Builds on the design lesions of VSST 108 Design I for Media.

30301.description: Provides basic understanding of the perceptual problems in drawing, including how three-dimensional objects can be represented on a two-dimensional surface.

33091.description: Provides basic understanding of the perceptual problems in drawing, including how three-dimensional objects can be represented on a two-dimensional surface.

30793.description: Introduces drawing of the human figure, with emphasis on composition and shape-area relationships.

31156.description: Introduces drawing of the human figure, with emphasis on composition and shape-area relationships.

31157.description: Introduces drawing of the human figure, with emphasis on composition and shape-area relationships.

30201.description: Introduces drawing of the human figure, with emphasis on composition and shape-area relationships.

31530.prereqs: VSST 110  Minimum Grade: D and VSST 111  Minimum Grade: D
31530.description: This is an advanced figure drawing class that bridges observational figure drawing and fashion illustration. While focusing on the structure of the body and its rhythms, students will also be introduced to elements of stylization of the figure.

31531.prereqs: VSST 110  Minimum Grade: D and VSST 111  Minimum Grade: D
31531.description: This is an advanced figure drawing class that bridges observational figure drawing and fashion illustration. While focusing on the structure of the body and its rhythms, students will also be introduced to elements of stylization of the figure.

31532.description: This is an advanced figure drawing class that bridges observational figure drawing and fashion illustration. While focusing on the structure of the body and its rhythms, students will also be introduced to elements of stylization of the figure.

33093.description: An introductory course to digital visual note-taking and painting. Observation is emphasized, as is visual organization, experimentation and conceptualization.  The class will meet at various locations on the Drexel campus as well as locations throughout the city.

33965.description: An introductory course to digital visual note-taking and painting. Observation is emphasized, as is visual organization, experimentation and conceptualization.  The class will meet at various locations on the Drexel campus as well as locations throughout the city.

30311.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
30311.description: This course augments the design studio experiences by introducing the influence of material characteristics and fabrication techniques.  Students learn how to design projects, reduce them to the specific parts, make the parts and assemble the work in a coordinated sequence.  Work is done in the Visual Studies Arts Annex woodshop.

32346.description: Painting Basics explores the fundamentals of making representational paintings. Working from direct observation, students learn the hands-on practices, materials and concepts of painting applicable to digital representation. Projects that use still life, interior and landscape subjects address design, composition and proportion as well as the effective use of color contrasts to create illumination and spatial depth. Water-based media will be used.

35263.description: Painting Basics explores the fundamentals of making representational paintings. Working from direct observation, students learn the hands-on practices, materials and concepts of painting applicable to digital representation. Projects that use still life, interior and landscape subjects address design, composition and proportion as well as the effective use of color contrasts to create illumination and spatial depth. Water-based media will be used.

30295.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
30295.description: New techniques, materials, and terminology, are introduced through a series of assignments based on observations of still life¿s and life models. Emphasis is placed on the application of color to articulate space and the development of individual expression.

30296.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
30296.description: New techniques, materials, and terminology, are introduced through a series of assignments based on observations of still life¿s and life models. Emphasis is placed on the application of color to articulate space and the development of individual expression.

30297.description: Expands the techniques, methods and materials covered in Painting 1. Representational and abstract styles are explored. Using techniques of observation and imagination, new approaches to painting are encouraged.

30298.description: Painting 3 expands on the ideas, methods, and materials, covered in Painting 1 and 2. Students formulate a self-styled project that focuses on a particular approach to painting. Emphasis is placed on mastering technical ability, and inventing imaginative solutions to challenges that arise in the project¿s completion.

30299.prereqs: VSST 103  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 106  Minimum Grade: D
30299.description: This course focuses on idea development, the creative application of materials and process, and introducing basic wood and metal working tools and techniques.  Projects bring these elements together with an emphasis on investigating new media and developing critical dialogue as it pertains to discussing and evaluating artwork.

31457.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
31457.description: Water based and photographic techniques are combined to create painterly and precise imagery in the building of a body of work. Techniques may include stencil-making, digitizing, mono-printing and color exploration. This course introduces the foundations of technical skills, language and theories used by the artist as printmaker.

31458.prereqs: VSST 102  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 105  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 109  Minimum Grade: D
31458.description: Water based and photographic techniques are combined to create painterly and precise imagery in the building of a body of work. Techniques may include stencil-making, digitizing, mono-printing and color exploration. This course introduces the foundations of technical skills, language and theories used by the artist as printmaker.

32022.prereqs: VSST 321  Minimum Grade: D or VSST 322  Minimum Grade: D
32022.description: Explores combination-printmaking, portfolio development and building a cohesive body of work.  Techniques may include mixed media printmaking, digital and alternative media. Students will document their work and develop an artistic statement.  The foundations of technical skills, language and theories.

34744.description: This interdisciplinary course is designed to provide an in-depth study of movement in dance, fashion, art, and animation, with a focus on figure drawing for motion. Through a combination of theory and practical exercises, the course explores the dynamic relationship between the human body, motion, garments, and animation. Students will develop their drawing skills and understanding of movement, while also exploring the expressive and collaborative aspects of drawing. By the end of the course, students will have a portfolio of work that demonstrates their ability to capture and convey motion through drawing and develop them into digital motion sequences. They will have strong skills in observing, seeing, analyzing, translating, and editing. Through digital editing, they will create film rhythms of their work. Going from live action, pencil to paper, to digital media.

31337.description: This introductory level course will provide the technical background for creative and professional digital communication on several platforms. Students will examine basic elements of design through the use of print and web based programs including Illustrator, Photoshop, InDesign, Acrobat, Powerpoint, Word Press and Constant Contact. Students will explore the current potentials, limitations, and issues related to the use of computer software for design application.

32376.description: This course is an introduction to making, the composing and decomposing of physical artifacts and digital technologies to suit a variety of purposes ¿ from practical to whimsical. Students will learn to take things apart, explore tools and materials, and build wondrous, wild art that¿s part science and part technology.

32867.description: This course is an introduction to making, the composing and decomposing of physical artifacts and digital technologies to suit a variety of purposes ¿ from practical to whimsical. Students will learn to take things apart, explore tools and materials, and build wondrous, wild art that¿s part science and part technology.

33943.description: A seminar course that examines different methods of problem solving and its role across disciplines.  The intention is to give the student a basis with which interdisciplinary projects can be approached in an innovative way and problem solving can be examined from multiple viewpoints.

33944.description: A seminar course that examines different methods of problem solving and its role across disciplines.  The intention is to give the student a basis with which interdisciplinary projects can be approached in an innovative way and problem solving can be examined from multiple viewpoints.

33946.description: A seminar course that examines different methods of problem solving and its role across disciplines.  The intention is to give the student a basis with which interdisciplinary projects can be approached in an innovative way and problem solving can be examined from multiple viewpoints.

34646.description: This course explores the spaces between buildings in an urban environment, their ¿publicness¿, and the programming that takes place within them. Critical assessment of public spaces will be key to the class, including how they are used, who is and is not included in the everyday use and creation of these spaces, and how best to design and maintain public space through placemaking principles.

34708.description: Seminar that examines 20th-century theories of architecture, including analysis and discussion of current theoretical positions.

34868.description: This course will provide a comprehensive and hands-on experience of various visualization tools used in product design. The course will assist you in developing an efficient workflow and a deeper understanding, enabling you to create high-quality product renderings. We will use AI-powered and generative tools, along with KeyShot and PhotoShop, to transform your preliminary sketches and ideas into accurate visual depictions of your solutions. This is a good opportunity to upgrade your current product images, take them to the next level, or create new high-end images for your portfolio.

35202.description: In this experiential learning course, students will gain practical, hands-on experience producing the Drexel Fashion show for 2024. Open to all majors and levels.

35253.description: Explorations will include applications of data visualizations ranging from print and web to environmental installations. Bar graphs, line graphs, area graphs, scatter charts, pie charts and other visual forms are investigated. The resulting projects will be static, dynamic or a combination of both.

35279.description: This course focuses on the critical analysis and study of videogames, one of the most profitable and prevalent forms of mass cultural media in the early 21st century. This course will center intersectional feminist approaches to the study of videogames, with a particular emphasis on race and other forms of embodied difference. In this course, students can expect to engage with games from many different genres, including art games (Hair Nah!), casual games (Diner Dash), first-person adventure games (Sunset), and 3D open-world games (Grand Theft Auto). Readings by games studies scholars including Kishonna Gray, Shira Chess, and Amanda Phillips will help us think through how embodied difference shapes how we play with (and are played by) our games. Over the course of the term, students will hone their argumentative and research skills through class presentations, a short midterm paper, and a final project that presents an original analysis of a videogame text for a general audience.

34653.description: Students will read branding case studies to comprehend why the phenomena of branding continues to drive our consumer society. Intellectual property rights, ethics and the legality surrounding various types of products and their branding will be investigated as students understand how to engage consumers in the global branding process.

34654.description: This course focuses on integrated retail buying and merchandise management and strategy development using technology. Students explore and analyze past, current and future trends in ecommerce technologies that primarily support the back end inventory, logistics and front end operations of the fashion apparel, accessory and home products industries.

34715.description: In this interdisciplinary studio, design students will collaborate with community members and local experts to create a series of Playful Learning interventions in the East Parkside Community of Philadelphia. Design teams will focus on developing Playful Learning initiatives for multiple sites, fostering intergenerational interaction and enriching children¿s cognitive and social development in the public spaces they encounter every day. Through assigned readings, lectures, community meetings and design charrettes students will acquire essential skills in community engagement, teamwork, inclusive design and placemaking. Additionally, grant funding has been secured in partnership with Playful Learning Landscapes Action Network, Watchdog and Drexel University, which will lead to the realization of some of the projects. For those interested, students also will have the chance to continue their involvement by participating in construction documentation and implementation activities for academic credit.

34709.description: Covers advanced architectural rendering, concentrating on the effects of light, shade, and color using the techniques of water-color rendering

34916.description: This course introduces bio-informed sciences into engineering design to help students develop engineering strategies for the built environment to promote human health and wellbeing. Topics covered include neuroscience, photobiology, biomimicry, biophilia, and chronobiology.

34438.description: The period between 1945's and 1990's constituted the time span of the liberation struggles from colonial power in several colonized territories in the African continent. The struggles that developed then can be also described as a Bulimundo period. Bulimundo, a Guinean and Creole expression, meant bulir o mundo--to agitate the world. In a way, it means to set a revolution in motion. This time span also referred by Okwui Enwezor as the short century, will be central period in this course, where we will study the Independence and Liberation Movements in Africa, using for this purpose biographies, independence speeches, photography, cinema,  novels and art.

34439.description: This class in an interdisciplinary, socio-historical introduction to rap music and hip hop culture.  Several themes will be explored including the origins of rap music as well as the role of urban youth and their notions of race and gender.  Record industry practices will also be investigated together with the impact of commercialism on hip hop.   We will also consider sexism, misogyny, and violence in both the music and culture.

35309.description: Colonization and capitalism deeply impacted the history of Africa, including in the way we understand the history. This course examines some of the silences in the historical record and considers the ways research can construct and reproduce the silences, as well as unveil them, in the history of the continent. What are these silences? What forces might be moving behind them? What hidden languages can we find when we question the silences? How do these silences affect our perception of the continent today? What are the ramifications in the world today?

34621.course_title: Black Noise: Fugitive Black Literature, Culture, and Thought
34621.prereqs: ENGL 103  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 113  Minimum Grade: D or ENGL 105  Minimum Grade: D
34621.description: This course examines experimental black cultural, literary, and theoretical forms, taking stock of their fugitive, outlaw, rupturing qualities and implications. While the class gets its name and anchoring idea from the abstract notion of ¿black noise¿ forwarded by Saidiya Hartman and Stephen Best, we will explore the actual noise of unruly black music, novels, film, short stories, visual art, poetry, and everyday expressive culture. With it, we will also investigate scholarship bearing out the ""wild"" methodologies and analyses that inform these experimental expressions -- from critical fabulation to mystic self-invention, from boundary-blurring black eco-poetics to a radical, everyday praxis of  ""deviance."" Together, we will engage the work of Akwaeke Emezi, Sun-Ra, M. Nourbese Philip, the St. John Coltrane Church, Henry Dumas, Kamau Braithwaite, Cameron Rowland, Kara Walker, maroon legends like Bras Coupé and geographies like the Great Dismal Swamp, and much, much more.

31642.description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

34455.description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

35409.description: Examines the diversity that exists in human culture. Uses lectures, films, and discussions to examine and illustrate the relationship between humans and their social/cultural systems.

34205.description: The eternal teaching of the different religions and how they address such issues as war, sexuality and economics.

33512.description: Introductory Arabic includes listening, speaking, reading and writing.  Offered all terms.

30762.description: This course is designed to provide a topical and interactive introduction to biology for non-majors.   Students will learn how trillions of tiny cells of our bodies work together in organ systems to use food for energy, to keep us alive, moving and healthy, and how information passes to subsequent generations.  This course is identical to BIO 107

30761.description: This course is designed to provide a topical and interactive introduction to biology for non-majors.   Students will learn how trillions of tiny cells of our bodies work together in organ systems to use food for energy, to keep us alive, moving and healthy, and how information passes to subsequent generations.   This course is identical to BIO 100.

30763.description: This course is designed to be a companion course to the BIO 107 lecture.   Labs are focused on providing students with a hands-on approach to science.  Topics include how cells generate energy from food, how certain characteristics are genetically encoded and the physiology of human systems and diseases.

35067.description: This inquiry based open enrollment course is designed to provide a topical and interactive exposure to the human health hazards associated with global climate change. Despite the burden of evidence of global climate change, it is not uncommon for the members of the general public to express apathy because the consequences seem so far removed in distance and time. The goal of this course is to bring climate change closer to home through a discussion of the imminent threat posed to human health.

30513.description: An introduction to the concepts of cell and function, cell and reproduction, cell communication, genetic inheritance, and population genetics.  The relevance of genetics to society and ethical issues are included.

30579.description: An introduction to the concepts of cell and function, cell and reproduction, cell communication, genetic inheritance, and population genetics.  The relevance of genetics to society and ethical issues are included.

32430.description: The course will survey physiological systems, including the respiratory, circulatory, homeostatic, excretory, digestive, immune, and reproductive systems in animals. In addition, students will learn about the relationships between organisms and the environment, including how humans impact ecosystems and the biosphere. This course has a lecture and recitation component.

32450.description: This lab course will survey anatomical systems in different classes of animals in order to compare the ways in which these animals obtain oxygen and other nutrients from the environment, transport these materials throughout the body, maintain homeostasis, and collect and eliminate waste products. Additionally, the course will emphasize relationships between living organisms and their environments.  Lab exercises in this course will explore anatomical systems, demonstrate major themes in ecology, and model how humans impact ecosystems.

30454.description: Introduces essential biological concepts to engineering students.  Content covers five core topics: cells, genetics, evolution, ecology and physiology with application to societal concerns about biotechnology, health, conservation biodiversity and bioethics.  Evolution will be woven throughout the course as a unifying theme in understanding all aspects of biology.

32463.description: In this course students will develop and implement hypothesis-driven experimental plans, to expand our knowledge of bacteriophages. In groups students will work collaboratively in lab to collecting data, interpreting results and drawing conclusions. The projects will be presented at the end of term to other students in the form of a poster presentation. This laboratory course is part of a sequence of three introductory courses.

30326.description: Intensive survey of the basic physiological mechanisms of cellular and human electrophysiology and the physiology of the muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and gastrointestinal systems.

31098.description: The aim of this course is to allow students to apply knowledge from biology courses to understand important articles from the frontiers of biology research, in order to develop critical thinking and problem solving skills. Students will learn to read primary research, to think critically about research and interpret data.

31100.prereqs: BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D
31100.description: In this course, students will cover essential topics in cell, molecular, and developmental biology. Topics, such as protein structure function relationships, enzymes, structural & functional properties of nucleic acids, transcription & translation, regulation of gene expression, eukaryotic cell structure, cell membranes and membrane transport.  Commonly used techniques in biochemistry, molecular & cellular biology will be discussed.

30259.description: Designed to familiarize student with laboratory techniques utilized in molecular biology, specifically DNA isolation, characterization, and manipulation.  Students work in teams to collect and analyze data and explain results in laboratory reports.  Weekly recitations preview and review theory and techniques used in the lab.  Some or all pre-requisites may be taken as either a pre-requisite or co-requisite.  Please see the department for more information. This is a writing intensive course.

34983.prereqs: BIO 121  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 124  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 126  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 132  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 133  Minimum Grade: D
34983.description: This course is an introduction to principles of organismal biology from the perspective of form, function and evolution of fish, amphibians, reptiles, mammals and birds.   Many biological principles are well known in this group of animals.   Data from areas as diverse as paleontology, ecology and molecular biology will be presented.

34924.prereqs: BIO 121  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 124  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 126  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 132  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 133  Minimum Grade: D

34925.prereqs: BIO 224  Minimum Grade: D  (BIO 224  may be taken concurrently with BIO 225)
34925.description: A hands-on laboratory course that complements BIO 224: Form, Function & Evolution of Vertebrates.   Students use the comparative approach to learn about the anatomy, physiology and evolution of vertebrates.  Laboratory work will be on campus and in the field trips to observe vertebrates in nature.

30261.description: An introduction to microbiology for students in the health professions.  Covers the diversity of microorganisms, their growth and how to control them.  An introduction to the principles of disease and pathogenicity, host interaction and immunological response.  Laboratories focus on the basic techniques to culture and student microorganisms.

31139.prereqs: (BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D ) and (BIO 124  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 132  Minimum Grade: D )
31139.description: This course illustrates the importance and utility of evolutionary perspectives on various topics related to human health. In addition to the "how" questions, this course also introduces the "why" questions. Various evolutionary hypotheses are examined. Arguments for and counter-arguments against each hypothesis are presented to foster understanding of each topic. Selected topics include infectious diseases, pathogen virulence, allergies/asthma, mental health/addiction, genetic disorders, diseases of civilization, sex, pregnancy, aging, and public health concerns.

32113.prereqs: BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D
32113.description: The focus of this course is the process of research and inquiry that leads to the isolation, characterization and identification of potential antibiotic producing microbial strains and species from soil. Students will work in small groups to collaboratively design and carry out their own experiments that will isolate these microorganisms. During this course, you will learn about the structure, metabolism, nutrition, and diversity of soil microorganisms.

31308.prereqs: BIO 100  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 101  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 107  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 109  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 122  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 141  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 131  Minimum Grade: D
31308.description: This course focuses on the biological responses to the physical and psychological stress, discussing in turn stress responses in various organ systems.  Emphasis is given to the analysis and evaluation of conflicting biological evidence on stress effects.

30236.prereqs: CHEM 242  Minimum Grade: D or CHEM 248  Minimum Grade: D
30236.description: Covers biochemical techniques ranging from basic laboratory preparatory work such as making solutions to the measurement of enzyme kinetics and substrate specificity.

31981.prereqs: CHEM 242  Minimum Grade: D or CHEM 248  Minimum Grade: D
31981.description: Covers biochemical techniques ranging from basic laboratory preparatory work such as making solutions to the measurement of enzyme kinetics and substrate specificity.

30238.prereqs: CHEM 242  Minimum Grade: D or CHEM 248  Minimum Grade: D
30238.description: Covers bioenergetics and metabolism; enzymes, substrates, products, coenzymes, transporters, pathways (catabolic and anabolic for carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, and nucleotides). Intracellular regulation, intercellular regulation, and how all this serves to meet the need of the cell and organism.

30239.prereqs: CHEM 242  Minimum Grade: D or CHEM 248  Minimum Grade: D
30239.description: Covers bioenergetics and metabolism; enzymes, substrates, products, coenzymes, transporters, pathways (catabolic and anabolic for carbohydrates, lipids, amino acids, and nucleotides). 34932.prereqs: BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
34932.description: In this course, students will apply their studies of chemistry and biology to understand how drugs: are designed, affect the body, and are affected by the body. Students can expect to learn the fundamentals of pharmacology, and to discuss current topics and novel approaches being used to design new therapeutics.

32308.prereqs: (BIO 214  Minimum Grade: D and BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D ) or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
32308.description: In this course, students will apply their studies of cell and molecular biology to understand cancer pathology.  Starting with a fundamental knowledge of normal cellular processes, students will learn how normal processes go awry in tumor development and metastasis, and the current approaches being used to develop new cancer therapeutics.

34936.prereqs: BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
34936.description: This course will focus on recent and important topics relevant to stem cell research and development.  Topics will include nuclear reprogramming and epigenetics, environmental influences on stem cell differentiation, stem cells and cancer, stem-cell-based therapies for heart and neurodegenerative disorders, stem cells and ageing, and politics of stem cell research.

32208.prereqs: BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D or (BIO 214  Minimum Grade: D and BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D )
32208.description: Covers molecular, cellular and physiological mechanisms underlying development of animals from gametes to adults. Covers the major stages and selected aspects of vertebrate development in importance animal model systems. Particular focus in on the importance of differential gene expression and its regulation in development.

31055.prereqs: BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
31055.description: Discusses the major viral groups, including biochemistry and molecular genetics of viral replication, structure, gene expression, latency, and role in disease.

31207.prereqs: BIO 214  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
31207.description: Course covers chemical composition and cellular function of organelles and other cellular structures, intra- and inter- cellular regulatory processes, intercellular communication, genetic mechanisms and analytical techniques.

30833.prereqs: BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
30833.description: Covers the fundamentals and principles of genetics with an emphasis on their relevance to human genetics and disease.  Topics include human genetic disorders, pedigree analysis and genetic testing, cytogenetics, epigenetics, genetics if cancer, gene therapy, stem cell research, human genomics and biotechnology.

31137.prereqs: BIO 218  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 348  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 349  Minimum Grade: D
31137.description: Autism disorders arise from changes in neurodevelopment that deeply affect how individuals interact with the world around them. As study of autism has increased over the past several decades, it has become clear that autism actually comprises a large, heterogeneous set of similar disorders, most of which are genetic in origin. In this class, we will study how neuronal cell biology is disrupted in known forms of autism, and how distinct forms of autism can arise from alterations in common cellular pathways. Further, we will discuss how these discoveries may lead to eventual treatments or cures.

31461.prereqs: BIO 214  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 348  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 349  Minimum Grade: D
31461.description: This is an advanced course on the current, primary literature in the area of neurodegeneration.  Students are expected to be conversant in areas of Genetics, Cell Biology, Molecular Biology, Biochemistry, and Neurobiology.  This is a discussion course based on reading current manuscripts from the primary literature.  Some or all pre-requisites may be taken as either a pre-requisite or co-requisite.  Please see the department for more information.

34931.prereqs: BIO 214  Minimum Grade: D or BIO 211  Minimum Grade: D
34931.description: Describes the classical hormones, their regulation and major clinical abnormalities. New directions in endocrinology, such as cellular regulation and cellular mediators of hormonal action are also considered. The major focus of the course will be on mammals, although some examples involving other vertebrates are included.

30210.description: This is a writing intensive course.

33829.description: Provides guided research in biology, molecular biology, microbiology, cell or human physiology, genetics, biochemistry, or biotechnology.

31876.description: Advanced Cell Biology is an up-to-date examination of the basic components and processes of the eukaryotic cell with the goal of understanding how these processes are integrated to drive complex cell behavior. Specifically, the course focuses on the molecular principles, modules and functions that sustain cell motility by integrating the essential concepts presented in class, including energy production, intracellular signaling, vesicular trafficking, and cell adhesion. Students will present cutting edge research publications and ideas spanning cell biology.

30834.description: Covers the fundamentals and principles of genetics with an emphasis on their relevance to human genetics and disease.  Topics include human genetic disorders, pedigree analysis and genetic testing, cytogenetics, epigenetics of cancer, gene therapy, stem cell research and human genomics and biotechnology.

34943.description: This course will focus on recent and important topics relevant to stem cell research and development.  Topics will include nuclear reprogramming and epigenetics, environmental influences on stem cell differentiation, stem cells and cancer, stem-cell-based therapies for heart and neurogenerative disorders, stem cells and ageing, and politics of stem cell research.

31306.description: Autism disorders arise from changes in neurodevelopment that deeply affect how individuals interact with the world around them.  As study of autism has increased over the past several decades, it has become clear that autism actually comprises a large, heterogeneous set of similar disorders, most of which are genetic in origin.  In this class, we will study how neuronal cell biology is disrupted in known forms of autism, and how distinct forms of autism can arise from alterations in common cellular pathways.  Further, we will discuss how these discoveries may lead to eventual treatments or cures.  Classes will include both lectures and discussion of recent papers from the scientific literature.

31462.prereqs: BIO 532  Minimum Grade: C or BIO 632  Minimum Grade: C
31462.description: This is an advanced course on the current, primary literature in the area of neurodegeneration.  Students are expected to be conversant in areas of Genetics, Cell Biology, Molecular Biology, Biochemistry, and Neurobiology.  This is a discussion course based on reading current manuscripts from the primary literature.

30921.description: This research seminar is a forum for Biology PhD students to present on their research to faculty and graduate student peers. Discussion of the scientific content as well as feedback on presentation style and quality follows every presentation.

32168.description: Kinetics and spectroscopy; Covers reaction kinetics, steady state approximation, chain reactions and unimolecular reactions, optical spectroscopy; Beer's Law, atomic spectra/simple atomic models, rotational and vibrational spectra, Raman spectra, term symbols and selection rules, lasers, molecular statistics, partition functions.

Covers SI units, unit factor calculations, states of matter, elements and compounds, energy, atoms, electronic configurations, ionic and covalent bonds, Lewis dot structures, shapes of molecules, chemical equations, stoichiometry, molarity, gas laws, nuclear chemistry, equilibrium between different states of matter, and some colligative properties of solutions.

Course covers physical and chemical properties of substances used in consumer products through an introduction to fundamental structures, nomenclature and properties of hydrocarbons, organize functional groups, polymers and biomolecules. 30526.description: Course will cover chemical explanations of everyday materials and phenomena.  The focus will be conceptual understanding, as opposed to a detailed quantitative treatment.

30896.description: Covers chemical analysis and data treatment, including chemical equilibrium, acid-base and redox reactions, and applications to gravimetric and titrimetric methods.
